Title: The Blog Is Live
Text:
So i've been coding for the last 2 weeks in my spare time  between work and hitting the gym at this blog that you are seeing right now, but this is still very much a work-in-progress.

I've allways been a fan of the .NET platform ,and my interest lately is ASP MVC. I absolutely love it, and the first step in doing so is coding my own small scale blog CMS.

As you can probably tell im kind of a  "designely challenged" person if i can say so and because i can't afford buying a good blog design right now, i've googled some free templates, filtered them out and chose this black - greenish one. I've left the credits and the footer intact and i dont claim this as being my own concoction.

As for the code itself, i've focused just on the main functionality used LINQ2SQL although last week , after going to a RONUA conference , i've learnead that MSF doesnt continue to develop Linq anymore just do only the bugfixing, instead going for Entity Framework as their ORM implementation and the basic CRUD operations in the backend Admin, and simple operation in the front end design.

Im leaving all the jQuery goodness, efects and magic  for as the last thing on the  // TODO :  list.

Title: Adding Gravatar To  An ASP MVC Project
Text:
Have you ever left a comment on a site , where you were asked just name/email/website info, and found in front an image  similar to this image here: 

And even more, did you notice that if you used the same credentials the image was the same?

All these sites use Gravatar to implement this image. It works both ways, for the gravatar user, each time you leave a comment you can leave your personal image wherever you comment ,and sites can benefit from this without having to save images for every user.

I wanted this feature on this blog and i had to write today this in my ASP MVC project, so lets get coding :

 public static class Gravatar 
 {
    public enum GRProtocol 
	{
	  Normal,// = "http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/",
	  Secure,// = "https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/"  
	}
	
	public enum GRSize 
	{
	  xs20,// = "s=20",
	  s40,// = "s=40",
	  m80,// = "s=80",
	  l160,// = "s=160",
	  xl200,// = "s=200"
	}
	
	public enum GRDefault 
	{
	   MysteryMan, // = "d=mm",
	   IdentIcon,// = "d=identicon",
	   MonsterId,// = "d=monsterid",
	   WaveAtar,// = "d=wavatar",
	   Retro,// = "d=retro"
	}
	
	public static string GetGravatarLink(string email,GRProtocol protocol, GRSize size, GRDefault defaultAvatar)
	{
	   string theEmail = email.Trim().ToLower();
	   
	   MD5 md5Hasher = MD5.Create(); 
	   
	   byte data = md5Hasher.ComputeHash(Encoding.Default.GetBytes(theEmail));
	   
	   StringBuilder sBuilder = new StringBuilder();
	   
	   //add the procol
	   
	   switch (protocol)
	   {
	      case GRProtocol.Normal:  sBuilder.Append("http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/"); break;
		  case GRProtocol.Secure:  sBuilder.Append("https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/"); break;
	   } 
	   
	   // Loop through each byte of the hashed data 
	   // and format each one as a hexadecimal string.
	   for (int i = 0; i<data.Length; i++)
	   {
	      sBuilder.Append(datai.ToString("x2"));
	   }
	   sBuilder.Append("?");
	   
	   //add the size
	   switch (size)
	   {
	     case GRSize.xs20: sBuilder.Append("&s=20"); break;
		 case GRSize.s40: sBuilder.Append("&s=40"); break;
		 case GRSize.m80: sBuilder.Append("&s=80"); break;
		 case GRSize.l160: sBuilder.Append("&s=160"); break;
		 case GRSize.xl200: sBuilder.Append("&s=200"); break;
	   } 
	   
	   //add the default gravatar when email is not on gravatar
	   switch (defaultAvatar) 
	   { 
	     case GRDefault.MysteryMan: sBuilder.Append("&d=mm"); break;
		 case GRDefault.IdentIcon: sBuilder.Append("&d=identicon"); break;
		 case GRDefault.MonsterId: sBuilder.Append("&d=monsterid"); break; 
		 case GRDefault.WaveAtar: sBuilder.Append("&d=wavatar"); break; 
		 case GRDefault.Retro: sBuilder.Append("&d=retro"); break; 
		}
		// Return the gravatar link 
		return sBuilder.ToString(); 
	  }
}

As you can see the end result represents a Gravatar url that will be specified in and <img> tag.

The url must contain the MD5 encoded email (trimmed and all lower case), and aditional parameters that you may include such as the size of the gravatar (i've predifed a couple here but basically you can request images anywhere from 1px up to 512px.

We can also have default images in case gravatar doesnt exist, and it also has support for secure protocols as well.

All you are left to do is call this in either a helper method or a view directly :

GetGravatarLink(c.Email,GRProtocol.Normal,GRSize.m80,GRDefault.MonsterId);

The URL result will look like : http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/19dc7b4182ba5c474300444465aee722?&s=80&d=monsterid

The Mentality for hitting the Gym
Text:
Wanted to blog for some time now about Bodybuilding, and i finally got some time and inspiration.

Since i have been a kid i've allways practiced a sport. I think its the one of the most important things that my parents encuranged me to practice.

First it was footbal (soccer) playing with the neighbour's kinds around the neighbourhood. I must admit, i wasn't too good at it but the idea is that everytime i heard my voice yealled at the yard door, i allways looked forward to just go around and have fun.

After a couple of years in junior high i started playing Basketball and it stuck with me all through highschool and a little in my first year of College.

*I love this game.*

Beeing in College in Bucharest, i didn't  have time to go anymore to hit the basketball field, nor were the my old friends allways available for a match, so at this point  i had to do something else and  then came the answer : go to the gym.

When i first stepped foot in a  gym i was weighing about 60KG (130punds for all you non-metric people) 180, eathing one meal , two the most  per day, could even do a flat Bench Press with no weights.

It was a underground gym, located in a huge empty room at a subway station near where i was living at that time. I've later learned that this is the place where the guys that go to bodybuilding competitions were training.

The first days / weeks were awkword, i didnt knew anything, i just moved the weights around trying to mimic the other bulked up guys there.

It was hard, really hard trying to integrate gym after work,but after i've noticed that my body was begining to transform, i was hooked.

There is a lot of motivational material out there and a lot of views on how you should be motivated to "go hard or go home". 

I personally think of bodybuilding and sports in general as something long term with a lifetime span mentality. I am setting milestones, objectives , short term goals and i push myself to reach them but they are positioned . I think you can apply this in any aspect of your life and it will surely keep you focused and on track.

Stay focused, train hard, set goals, set milestones and have fun. The results will come and trust me, you will be hooked.
